text: <@UC6SUUPRC> So... in 2023, can we use IBMQClient+Yao to work with a 1000+ qubits？:relieved:

elements.text: So... in 2023, can we use IBMQClient+Yao to work with a 1000+ qubits？

text:
I mean, it currently works, right?

If there're no breaks, we'll just see more options in the IBMQClient, as they grow, right?
Or do you mean that our system wouldn't be able to store those 1000+ qubits before they get sent to IBM Q for running?

elements.text:

text: I don’t if there will be 1000+ qubits

elements.text: I don’t if there will be 1000+ qubits

text: and I don’t like predicting things in this way

elements.text: and I don’t like predicting things in this way

text:
Ohhh... that way, yeah
You're right, its useless making predictions if we ourselves are not doing it:slightly_smiling_face:
Even then, stuff might not play out as we thought

text: Of course, even if they do have some 1000+ qubit systems, would you be able to afford time using them? Would they even be made available over the internet like the simple NISQ ones available now?
